scienceCenter.name: Black Holes, the Sound of Cosmic Collisions
scienceCenter.description: Our exhibit will demonstrate how Black Holes can be observed, and how scientists are able to use Supercomputers to simulate the collisions of Black Holes, find Black Holes using LIGO, and determine how Black Holes affect everything around them. In our exhibit you will use the gravity from Black Holes to control lasers, bend light and save the Earth from alien invasion, or you can play ping pong. Come see a scale model of LIGO and learn how scientists detected the invisible.
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Hans-Peter Bischof, Manuela Campanelli, Joshua Faber, Jake Lange, Carlos Lousto, Vassilios Mewes, Jason Nordhaus, Jam Sadiq, Andrew Williamson, Daniel Wysocki, Yosef Zlochower, Dennis Bowen

scienceCenter.name: Cosmic Companions: From Planets to Black Holes
scienceCenter.description: Satisfy your cosmic curiosity! Let members of the graduate program in Astrophysical Sciences and Technology explain astrophysical concepts and phenomena and teach you about some telescopes we use and how they work. Learn about The Great American Eclipse, a total solar eclipse across the US on 8/21/17. Come observe the Sun (weather permitting) and compete in a game of Astro Trivia to win cool prizes! This exhibit will be OUT OF THIS WORLD!
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Kristina Punzi, Chi Nguyen, Jared Wofford, Zach Silberman, Kevin Cooke, Triana Almeyda, Andy Robinson, Yashashree Jadhav, Michael Richmond, Tanmayee Gupte, Ashley Frank, Muyun Liu, Victoria Butler, Brittany Vanderhoof, Annie Dickson-Vandervelde, Meaghann Stoelting, Jen Connelly, Krystal Tyler, Gabriel Guidarelli, Jesse Bublitz, Secret Lizard Agent Trent Seelig, Ektaben Shah, Jake Lange, Jeyhan Kartaltepe, Mike Zemcov

scienceCenter.name: Cradle to Cradle Product Design Challenge
scienceCenter.description: Cradle to Cradle is the concept of designing a product so that once it reaches the end of its life, all the materials can be reused or can decompose back into the environment. This challenge incorporated both the sustainable product design process with a feasible business model for a new shaving razor design.
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Daniel Rouleau, Morgan Mistysyn, Krista Stainslow, Alyssa Reome, Wil Rudan, Tyler Valentine, Gary Capriotti, Victoria Nolletti, Shannon Driess

scienceCenter.name: Creating Parabolic Curves From Straight Lines
scienceCenter.description: Curved geometric designs can be made of only straight lines that are strategically spaced and positioned. Come see a large scale version of one of these designs and appreciate the neat geometry!
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Renee Meinhold, Erin Neidhart, Ellen Baillie, Nate Barlow, Logan Melican, Jack Bates, Ender Erimhan, Mike Spink, Connor Devitt, Adam Giammarese, Vu Le

scienceCenter.name: Data Analytics for i-ALERT
scienceCenter.description: Through a partnership with ITT Goulds Pumps, students working in the Data and Predictive Analytics Center at RIT have developed a dashboard that facilitates machine health monitoring, data analysis and machine failure prediction. Visitors will have the opportunity to examine real-time data and to learn about Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT).
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Heather Cottone, Mihail Barbosu, Dorin Patru, Austin Bodzas, Daniel Mitchell, Alec Herbert

scienceCenter.name: DIY Science: Experiments You CAN Try at Home!
scienceCenter.description: Big science experiments and demonstrations are always really exciting, but we're always told "don't try this at home." RIT COSSAB is proud to present real experiments that you CAN try at home. These experiments include seeing how water travels through plants, seeing sound waves, making glowing water, and using chemistry and cabbage to create color-changing litmus paper. Swing by to learn how you can be a scientist anywhere!
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Callie Donahue, Ashley Adair, Madison Ricco, Luke Laffey, Maria Cervantes, Erin McCarthy, Gregory Curtin, Jeremy Kane

scienceCenter.name: Engineers for a Sustainable World
scienceCenter.description: Check out what Engineers for a Sustainable World is up to! A presentation run completely off solar power, cardboard made of algae, and more!
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Gabriel Kramer, Andrew Loriot, Chris Kratzer, Angela Gallo, Mackenzie Frye, Lauren Kepenis, Andrew Fisher, Brian Yu, Josh Noble, Wil Rudan, Jared Peters, Emmanuel Okafor, Seth Sieger, Hannah Weppner

scienceCenter.name: Experimenting with Aquaponics and Vertical Farming
scienceCenter.description: A student group part of Engineers for a Sustainable World has done research on sustainable farming methods. Using this research, we have designed and created a small scale self-sustaining aquaponics system on a budget. This system allows plants to grow almost twice as quickly than traditional farming methods in a dense, soil-less environment. We will demonstrate how families can grow plants such as leafy greens, tomatoes, and flowers with limited time and money.
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Briana Goold, Sarah Nick, Ignacio Martos, Josh Evans

scienceCenter.name: Explorations in Physics
scienceCenter.description: Come and explore everyday physics with RIT's Society of Physics Students. Common things we interact with everyday are more mysterious then they may seem. From a simple spinning bike tire to redirecting light with custom made gelatin lenses, see how we can predict seemingly random every day events with accuracy.
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Zackary Santos, Kellianne Kornick, Justin Gallagher, David Kelley, Alex Kolberg, Connor Shamis, Leo Sutter, Brian Wojcik, Matthew Delfavero, Jason Walls, Tessalie Caze-Cortes, Wyatt Wetzel, Samuel Washburn, Jacob Palmerio, Rifet Musedinovic, Ian Kecskes, Zachary Assenmacher, Thomas Kilmer, Devon Christman, Quinton LoRe, George McMurdy, Myers Weidner, Benjamin Scott, Christian Cammarota, Stefano Marin, Daniel Gysbers, Frank Schooner, Henry Huang, Lucas Shadler, Ryan Warner

scienceCenter.name: Frankenfoods
scienceCenter.description: Our exhibit is about mankind's role in the evolution of plants whether direct or indirect. We hope to teach our guests the truth about GMO's; how they are helpful for society and the environment when used properly. We aim to teach people about selective breeding, the process of creating transgenic plants and how they have impacted society. We hope to debunk outdated myths and answer any questions that come up.
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Isabelle O'Bryon, Melissa Barton, Josh Evans, Ali Cala , Nic Burns, Spencer Richman, Lily Cisco, Jake Haut, Grace Morales, Yara Rose, Nicole Cavanaugh, Bethany Hartley, Callie Donahue, Maria Cervantes, Akua Donkor

scienceCenter.name: Fruity DNA Necklaces
scienceCenter.description: All living organisms contain DNA, the stuff of life. We will guide you through a simple procedure to extract DNA from your favorite fruit, using household ingredients. You will be able to see the DNA in a tiny tube, and we'll make a necklace for you to take home.
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Dawn Carter, Karl Brylow, Janessa Morelli, Nana Aikins, Nicole Pannullo, Breanna Laber, Krista Rohan, Zayneb Jaff, Tilor Hallquist, Rachel Taylor, Seema Thomas, Hailey Richmond-Boudewyns, Carter Moleski, Liam Megraw, Zach Wentlent, Kelleen McGuinness, JENIFER ROSETE, IMAN FARID, ADITYA GUPTA, MOHAMMED ALSHAMMARY, Matthew Hulbert, Cole Roemer, Andres Mora, Andy Doland, Cooper Norris, Nicole Cavanaugh, Mariel Pridmore, Loryn Johnson

scienceCenter.name: How Does RIT Use a Greenhouse?
scienceCenter.description: Come visit the RIT greenhouse to see how it is used for research and community support ! There will be plant collections to visit and research students present to talk to you about their exciting research. There will also be details on the community garden and how to find it. While supplies last, there will be free seed giveaways and plantlets to take home.
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Jennifer Liedkie, Mark Liedkie, amanda dolan, Nic Burns

scienceCenter.name: Impacts of Climate Change on the Finger Lakes Wine
scienceCenter.description: Grape production and wineries represent a significant part of the economy of the Finger Lakes region. Students in Environmental workshop are currently developing models that use data from real grape growers to predict the economic impacts climate change may have on this important industry.
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Corey ptak

scienceCenter.name: Just Sharing Something Viral
scienceCenter.description: Ahhhh, viruses! A single virus infection could turn us into zombies - what a terror! But did you know that bacterial eaters called phages are viruses, too? Yes, and these viruses can also save lives; they are more friendly than you think. ....Come celebrate 100 years of phages with us!
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Julie Thomas, Mazin Mar , Ali Cala , Sara Mallory, Rebecca Walden, Sitisarahfatin Shamsuddin, Nor Athirah Ahmadtarmizi, Nur Hidayah Mohd Rasid, Loura Nasif, Nurul Humaira Mohd Redzuan , Nur Amira Md Amin, Andy Lu, Alexandra Mace, Grace Morales, Zur Raiha Hamim, Jazrina Mohd Jasmi, Nik Norzapina Seman, Bazla Ali, Melissa Barton

scienceCenter.name: Liquid Nitrogen Ice Cream
scienceCenter.description: We will be using liquid nitrogen to make ice cream in front of spectators. We will be using dairy products and sugar with various flavored syrups and toppings to make ice cream by mixing them with liquid nitrogen which freezes the water in the dairy. We will be using Milk, Heavy cream, and half and half. The spectators will not be handling the liquid nitrogen, only brothers and faculty. We will be wearing gloves due to handling food and will be serving the ice cream to the spectators.
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Trent Mochel, Elliot Patnode, Megan Owens, Daniel Verrico, Eve Arnold, Kyle Tezanos, Ishita Jalan, Kris Wong, Zachary Protich, Matthew Bonney, Joe Hunt, Luke Lanza, Dennis Bogdan, Hannah Sheldon, William Charbonneau, Hailee Wetherbee, Anthony Cannella

scienceCenter.name: Math Arts & Crafts
scienceCenter.description: Join us in making hexaflexagons, geometric shapes out of balloons, and exploring combinatorics with dominoes!
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Matthew Loiacono, Josh Chasen, Hector Escobedo, Jason Carr

scienceCenter.name: Nanomaterials: Learn and Play Demonstrations
scienceCenter.description: Amazing nanomaterials that are revolutionizing our daily life.
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Michael Cross

scienceCenter.name: Nanomaterials: Learn and Play Demonstrations
scienceCenter.description: Thrilling and adventurous demonstrations of Nanomaterials such as a battery powered iron extractor which uses a battery and wires to create a magentic field to separate nanoiron particles mixed with sand. Bell peppers and other fruits are used to examine the battery function. Hastening the biological process and the effect of it on the developed voltage is demonstrated.
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Kalathur Santhanam, Kris Wong, Nuzhet Nihaar Nasir Ahamed, Andres Dabdoub , Devarsh Manishbhai Shah, Thomas White , Kenny Baptiste , David Hurley , Martin Dann , Wenxuan Fan, Olivia SCHEIBEL , Karen Soule

scienceCenter.name: Parabolic Mirror
scienceCenter.description: Come see how light can be reflected and focused in our specially shaped mirror!
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Travis Chaikin, Jarrod Daniels, William Woodman, Jake Rivas, Alexandra Capodicasa

scienceCenter.name: Pie a Football Player
scienceCenter.description: Throw a football though our team's cut out. Hit the target and win a chance to throw a whip cream pie at a member of our club!
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Tyler Zimmermann, Sal D'Amico, Chaquan Smith, Jonah Sharp, Joe Kubiak, Cameron Garnes

scienceCenter.name: PyPad: Making Music Fun!
scienceCenter.description: PyPad is a large scale way to make music. Using RaspberryPi3, Novation Launchpad, and Python, we created one of the coolest ways to make a light and music show!
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Emely Giraldo

scienceCenter.name: Radio IP Pi Hotspot
scienceCenter.description: Our project is a self contained unit that serves as an interface between radio and the Internet. There are multiple networks that Amateur Radio Operators (Hams) have created in order to connect radio systems over the internet. This allows a Ham in Rochester to talk to a Ham in Ireland with a very small amount of power with a small handheld radio. Our project connects a radio on a chip to a Raspberry Pi, which serves as the interface to the Internet.
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Christopher Culpepper, Ali Kazi, damodar Adhikari

scienceCenter.name: Recover Rochester: How Do You Stack Up?
scienceCenter.description: Compete against your friends and family to see who can stack the most containers without knocking having them fall over! Winner will be given a small prize. You can also take a guess at how much food we recover from dining halls every week by checking out our display of food boxes! Closest guesses will be featured on our Facebook page at the end of the festival.
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Maryah Glover, Daniel Herzig, Caleb Churchill, Allison Blakeley, Allison Moulton, Mars Ballantyne, Katherine Larson, Corey Wrigley, Walter Schaertl, Ryan Le Tourneau

scienceCenter.name: Redefining the Goldilocks Zone
scienceCenter.description: Trappist-1 is a star that was recently discovered to have three planets around it in the Goldilocks Zone. But what's the Goldilocks Zone? It's the standard for whether a planet's capable of supporting life, currently based on the presence of liquid water, but this experiment set out to see if that qualification could be redefined by simulating climates of planets with varying temperatures and atmospheres, and if they'd still result in organic compounds, and thus have the potential for life.
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Lindsey Blomquist, Roger Dube, Morgan Bauer, Catherine O'Halloran, Connor Brennan, Kayla Dingman, Valerie Yost, Joshua Monteverde, Daihlia Beckford, Guillaume Bellefleur, Michael Grant, Austin Clift

scienceCenter.name: RIT Equestrian Club
scienceCenter.description: We will have a Kentucky Derby themed table and a live pony to help promote our club. Visitors will be allowed to pet the pony.
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Morgan Marriott, Victoria Nolletti, Krista Stainslow, Emma Bronner

scienceCenter.name: Science Playground
scienceCenter.description: A fun series of exhibits perfect for entertaining younger guests while still offering interesting information to older guests as well, comprising entertaining demonstrations and simple explanations. We will show how a kaleidoscope works, talk about hydrophobic sand, a large foam generating reaction and more.
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Travis Chaikin, Jarrod Daniels, Bryanne McDonough, Daniel Gysbers, Alex Gysbers, hanna berga, Sheldon Lewis II, Chris Tewksbury, Jonah Saitz, Johnny Cuevas, Rea Rudesil, Alexis Rudesil, Nathaniel Mincy, Manya Sankaran, Flint DiLella, Andrew Bentkowski, Brian Hillier , Natasha Nigam

scienceCenter.name: Seeing the Invisible
scienceCenter.description: See the heat coming from your hand with a Schlieren imaging system! Schlieren imaging produces streaks of dark and light bands that allow us to see very small differences in air density and watch heat rise from our hands.
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Lauren Taylor, Zichao Han, Jacob Wirth, Kamran Binaee, Anton Travinsky, Ryan Ford, Ying-ju Chu, Dmitry Vorobiev

scienceCenter.name: SMASH: The Coffee-Ring Effect and Tear Films
scienceCenter.description: Have you ever noticed when someone spills their coffee on the table and leaves it there to dry what is left behind is a ring? This phenomenon is called "the coffee-ring effect." It can be explained by the concepts of conservation of mass and advection. A similar mechanism causes the formation of eye boogers, eww! In this exhibit, participants will conduct a set of experiments to connect the mathematical idea of slope with physical phenomena relate to advection.
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Kara Maki, Michael Schertzer, Collin Burkhart, Jordana O'Brien, Xi Li, Sanu Magar, Jada Brown, Anah Sadique, Mattie Valinsky, Keely Masters, Sarah Miller, Alyssa Williams, Zo Masters, Marisa Wright, Avye Stathopoulos, Xanthe Plymale, Lariba Aboyer, Abby Herman, Amanda Heron, Sophia Braithwaite, Anna McDonald, Eshmeron Subba, Payton Yelle, Manisha Giri, Kaitlin Waters, Juliana Lutzer, Jillian Russo, Sam Simpson, Keren Park

scienceCenter.name: SPEX (Space Exploration): CubeSat Visualization
scienceCenter.description: 3D visualization of a cube satellite in reaction to a physical 3D printed satellite model being manipulated.
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Austin Bodzas, Jeremy Quinn, Chris Johnson, Samuel Chen, Walter Schaertl, Alec Herbert, Amber Dubill, Daniel Mitchell, Mihail Barbosu

scienceCenter.name: SPEX Arcjet Thruster
scienceCenter.description: An arcjet thruster is a type of electro-thermal propulsion, which means it uses electricity to heat up a gas. Come see this propulsion system that could play a significant role in helping humanity continue to explore our solar system and probe the far reaches of space.
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Philip Linden, Anthony Higgins, Matt Giuffre, Dylan Bruce, James Gandek

scienceCenter.name: SPEX: Astrotracking Team
scienceCenter.description: RIT SPEX's Astrotracking team will show off our smaller telescopes, including an alt-az telescope mount made from the ground up. Visitors can take a look at the telescopes and play around while learning about the engineering/process behind tracking objects from space. There will also be displays of astrophotography done by the group.
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Amber Dubill, Marilyn Wolbert, Evan Putnam, James Parkus, Austin Bodzas, Drew Walters, Mihail Barbosu, Ryan Portocarrero

scienceCenter.name: SPEX: High Altitude Ballooning
scienceCenter.description: We will have a balloon launch outside the Gordon Field House at 10am, and a booth in Gosnell Hall which will house a poster about high altitude ballooning and a selection of our previous payloads. We will also have a video display showing our previous launches.
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Drew Walters, Amber Dubill, Austin Bodzas, James Parkus, david breen, Alec Herbert, Samuel Chen, Ryan Portocarrero, Mihail Barbosu, Daniel Mitchell, Evan Putnam, Dorin Patru, Christian Pape, Matthew Sisson

scienceCenter.name: SPEX: Orbit Simulation and Design
scienceCenter.description: SPEX Structures and Thermals team project consists of designing and manufacturing what is better known as a CubeSat. Along with the assembly, we will also be displaying two virtual simulations; a thermal simulation and a stress analysis of our CubeSat design and a thermal simulation and stress analysis of an existing "for purchase" CubeSat that we would be using for a comparison. Also, we are planning to show an orbital simulator that we will design and manufacture ourselves.
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Nicole Cuello Wajdowicz, Jacob Gutwirth, Brandon Alerte, Varun Bhalerao, William Dzialak, Amber Dubill

scienceCenter.name: SPEX: Propulsion
scienceCenter.description: The SPEX propulsion exhibit will feature a cold gas propulsion system contained in a vertical test stand that was used to calculate the thrust of the system through a series of tests. These tests included different area ratios, nozzle geometries, and nozzle determination methods. The series of nozzles will be on display with one mounted upon the system. There will be various videos and pictures displaying our experience designing, fabricating, and testing this system.
scienceCenter.exhibitors: James Parkus, Amber Dubill, Neil Bhasme, Varun Bhalerao, Jacob Gutwirth, Hunter Collins, Elise King, Mihail Barbosu

scienceCenter.name: SPEX: Real Time Sensor Visualization
scienceCenter.description: SPEX develops several devices that generate useful data. This Imagine RIT display will include a live demonstration of an application for collecting data and visualizing it across multiple computers and displays. The web client has multiple, different interactive visualizations that showcase the data in unique ways. Also, because of the web-based nature of the application, attendees can pull up the application on their smartphones for a more interactive experience.
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Thomas Tarazevits, Amber Dubill, Mihail Barbosu

scienceCenter.name: SPEX: Satellite Comms and Telescope Automation
scienceCenter.description: Our exhibit will feature two distinct parts. The first of which will be showing the capabilities of Software defined radios to get satellite images. We will display the images we have gotten as well as show how to tune to specific radio stations. The second part will be a live feed of a telescope which can be moved remotely.
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Evan Putnam, Amber Dubill, Henry Yaeger, Ryan Portocarrero, Helen O'Connell, John LeBrun, Marilyn Wolbert, Mihail Barbosu

scienceCenter.name: The Science of Art
scienceCenter.description: Join the Women in Science (WISe) group as we explore the science and math behind art! See examples of art in nature, and make your own scientific art project to take home with you.
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Lea Michel, Elizabeth DiCesare, Kristina Driscoll, Mandy Nevins, Becca Brent, Emily Kiesel, Susan Tian, Milky Abajorga, Vina Macias, Lauren Knappenberger, Samantha Lauro, Ei Thinzar Phyo, Durnian Parulski-Seager , Shivani Phadke, Katharine Umphred-Wilson, Andronique Zacharakis, Bradley Hanel, Brooke Seamans, Jessica Fung, Nur Hidayah Mohd Rasid, Maria Jia

scienceCenter.name: The Upper and Lower Limit of the Goldilocks Zone
scienceCenter.description: In this experiment, the potential for life on other planets was tested. This was tested by determining which gas mixtures inside of a controlled atmosphere would produce amino acids and simple sugars, the building blocks for life. The amount of these gases was also altered between experiments in order to determine if different concentrations would produce larger amounts of these building blocks.
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Jared Luce, Aaron Chou, Francisco Morrison, Julia O'Halloran, Elizabeth Siciliano, Julia Faraone, Lindsey Decoursey

scienceCenter.name: Trebuchet
scienceCenter.description: We plan to demonstrate 2 small scale trebuchet. We will be displaying our take on the siege weapons used in the Middle Ages and talking about how they function. This will show the electiveness of the device as well as how it works as you scale it up, as well as a larger scale trebuchet.
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Travis Chaikin, Jarrod Daniels, Julia solinas, Ryan Wills, Stanley Goldstein, Tyler Chinsky, Nils Aldeborgh

scienceCenter.name: Vacuum Cannon
scienceCenter.description: Using the power of vacuums to launch ping pong balls!
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Travis Chaikin, Jarrod Daniels, Tyler Chinsky

scienceCenter.name: Weigh In On Your Favorite Color
scienceCenter.description: What's your favorite color? Did you know that colors are often made up of mixtures of primary colors? Starting with different amounts of primary colors of light, for example red, green, and blue, they add up to a new color in a weighted average. Could be white, purple, RIT orange, or anything you imagine! We let you control it with force on scales. Come contribute your weight to a color mixture in our lights and see how this all works in our interactive physical demo!
scienceCenter.exhibitors: Michael Murdoch, Chris Thorstenson, Morteza Maali Amiri, Samuel Morillas Gomez, Susan Farnand, Mark Fairchild, Lili Zhang, fnu Anku, Matt Ronnenberg, Gaurav Sheth
